questions.prompt: Canon, Apocryphal, Gnosticism
questions.answer:
Canon - these are the books of the Bible that were considered to be truth.

Apocryphal - meaning strange, hidden, secret, used in relation to books that were non-canonical, specifically books that were considered to be scripture but did not have the same authenticity as books that were canon

Gnosticism - this is a modern term, related to the group of mystic religious philosophies popular in the second and third centuries AD.  

Essential to Gnosticism is the idea that the physical world is evil and the spiritual world is pure. Gnostics believed that this world was created by an evil god (known as the Demi-Urge) who trapped spiritual beings within evil physical realities. To escape from this physical world one must realize, through secret knowledge (γνῶσις - gnosis in Greek, of where we get the group’s namesake) that they too are divine, and by this realization (knowledge revealed to humanity by Aeons) people can break free and release their divine spirit. Gnostic belief often appropriated already existing religious figures into the pantheon of the Aeons. Within “Christian Gnosticism” Jesus is portrayed as an Aeon who communicates this secret knowledge to his followers. Gnostic literature, such as the Gospel of Thomas, commandeered the names of key biblical characters in an attempt to popularize and legitimize these ideas. 

Other Gnostic Gospels
The Gospel of Judas
The Gospel of Mary
The Gospel of Thomas
The Gospel of Philip
The Gospel of Peter

------

questions.prompt: Given this standard, what would be the books that had obvious connections to Jesus that were included within our Bible? What canonical books might have had an indirect association. For example, Luke was not an apostle, why would his Gospel have been considered scripture?
questions.answer:
Given this standard, what would be the books that had obvious connections to Jesus that were included within our Bible?
All four Gospels were accepted because they claim eyewitness or apostolic origins and their content is mutually consistent. Luke, though not one of the Twelve, collected eyewitness reports and was connected to Paul; John was an eyewitness apostle. Acts (same author as Luke) continues the apostolic narrative. Mark and Matthew have apostolic ties (Mark via Peter; Matthew traditionally an apostle). Early canon recognition used multiple tests — apostolic origin or close association, conformity to the rule of faith, widespread usage, and perceived spiritual authority — not a single proof.

questions.prompt: What canonical books might have had an indirect association. For example, Luke was not an apostle, why would his Gospel have been considered scripture?
questions.answer:
Luke’s Gospel was trusted because he explicitly gathered eyewitness reports, was linked to Paul (an apostle), his work fit established teaching about Jesus, and it was widely used and affirmed by early church leaders — meeting the practical tests the church applied for canonicity.

Mark — indirect: traditionally Peter’s interpreter/assistant; accepted because it preserved Peter’s eyewitness testimony and matched the rule of faith.
Luke & Acts — indirect: Luke wasn’t an apostle but was Paul’s companion, explicitly used eyewitness sources (Luke 1:1–4), shows careful historical method, and circulated widely with apostolic endorsement.
Hebrews — indirect/uncertain authorship; accepted because it reflected Pauline theology, circulated with Paul’s letters, and proved useful and orthodox in worship.
Pastoral epistles (1–2 Timothy, Titus) — debated authorship but accepted due to Pauline attribution, ecclesial usefulness, and doctrinal fit.
James, Jude — authorship tied to Jesus’ family/early leaders (not apostles in the Twelve sense for James the brother); accepted because of early use, orthodox teaching, and apostolic-era provenance.
2 Peter, Revelation — had longer debates but were accepted on grounds of apostolic connection, theological consonance, and widespread church usage.
Why indirect works were accepted:

Apostolic connection (authorship, close associate, or direct testimony used).
Conformity to the church’s “rule of faith” (orthodox teaching about Christ).
Widespread liturgical and catechetical use across churches (catholicity).
Endorsement by respected church leaders (patristic attestation) and perceived spiritual/inspirational authority.

outline.summary: What warning is repeated across these passages?
points: Proverbs 30:5–6
Deuteronomy 12:32
Revelation 22:18–19
Matthew 15:1–9
Pay attention to the language of adding, taking away, commands, words, and authority.
Proverbs 30:5–6 sets the foundation: every word of God is pure; He is a shield; do not add to His words lest you be found a liar.

questions.prompt: What warning is repeated across these passages?
questions.answer: The repeated warning is about the danger of adding to or taking away from God's Word. Proverbs 30:5–6 opens with this command, followed by multiple passages showing the consequences: those who add to Scripture are found to be liars (Deuteronomy 12:32, Revelation 22:18–19), they replace truth with human traditions and doctrines (Colossians 2:20–22, Matthew 15:1–9), and ultimately they follow the pattern of Satan, who is 'the father of lies' (John 8:44). The warning emphasizes purity of the Word and the necessity of maintaining God's authority over human interpretation.

outline.summary: A — Every word of God is pure
points: The words that we have are correct and accurate; Scripture invites scrutiny because truth is not afraid of the light.
Context lets us respond when verses are pulled out to accuse God of being unloving, unjust, or contradictory.
Examples: Elisha and the bears (2 Kings 2:23–25);
Criticism:

42 children were mauled by God just because they made fun of this prophet for being bald - that doesn't seem like a very forgiving thing to do, also the response is incredibly out of measure with the action.  There is no justice here, no mercy, no forgiveness - how can you say you serve a loving God when He does things like this?!
Response:

There is a lot to this one, and not all of it is clear just reading through the scripture.  If you don't have a full understanding of context, not only Biblical, but cultural context of the time - then you're not going to have a satisfying rebuttal for this one.  Let's start with the idea that these were children, the Hebrew word that is used in place of 'youths' here has a fairly broad definition - most likely we can know that these youths that are referenced are older teenagers or men in their young 20's.  We see Joseph called naar at 17 years old in Genesis 37:2, Jeremiah when he was called into ministry in Jeremiah 1:6 and King Ahab defeated an army lead by 232 naarim in 1 Kings 20.  These are not likely small children but young adults - very much could have been a threat to Elisha, and in the comfort of our own church, I would go so far as to say that it is likely that violence was going to happen because of God's response - which isn't often as quick as it works in this instance.

Then, to go on further, the taunt wasn't purely about Elisha being bald - in that time, it was closer to calling someone effeminate, I won't use the more vulgar words - but I'm sure all or most of you know them and can substitute here.  Then when they were saying 'Go up' they were referencing and earlier event where Elijah - his teacher and mentor - had, in fact, gone up to heaven and left to be in the presence of God.  Which, not only are they saying they don't want him there, but that they are willing to help him go be with Elijah but they wouldn't have the means of God to get him there so I imagine they would resort to more violent methods.

If you are rebutting someone who is not Christian, stick to what the scripture says - don't editorialize, like I did for us here, but know the culture of the time, know the truth of Scripture and who it was written to - the Jewish people at the time would have understood all of this just by growing up where they did.
Let's do another and then we will move on
Example: Kill everyone in a city (Deuteronomy 20:16–17);
Criticism:

God commanded the Israelites to “utterly destroy” every person living in the Canaanite cities God was giving them. They were instructed to “not leave alive anything that breathes”—to kill every man, woman, child, and animal (Deut. 20:16–17). Why would a good God have the Israelites exterminate entire groups of people, including women, children, and animals?
Response (resources: https://tinyurl.com/2NEFX888
Purity is proven under pressure but revealed by exposure—God's Word stands up to testing (Psalm 119:105; John 3:20).

questions.prompt: What is purity? What do you know about gold refining?
questions.answer: Purity is proven under pressure but it is revealed by exposure. In Zechariah 13:9, God refines His people as silver is refined and gold is tested—the refining process removes impurities. Just as gold loses its purity with even small amounts of contamination, God's Word must remain pure and uncontaminated by human additions or deletions.

questions.prompt: Example: Elisha and the bears (2 Kings 2:23–25) — what's the criticism and how do we answer?
questions.answer: Criticism: 'God mauled 42 children just for mocking a bald prophet—no justice or mercy.' Response: The Hebrew 'youths' (na'ar) often refers to older teens/young men (e.g., Joseph at 17 in Genesis 37:2; fighters in 1 Kings 20). The taunt 'Go up, you baldhead' was an aggressive, likely threatening insult (calling him effeminate and dismissing Elijah's ascent), and violence was plausible. God's swift judgment defends His prophet and signals the seriousness of rejecting His messenger. Context—biblical and cultural—shows this was not a petty overreaction against toddlers.

questions.prompt: Example: Kill everyone in a city (Deuteronomy 20:16–17) — what's the criticism and how do we answer?
questions.answer: Criticism: 'God commands genocide against Canaanite cities—men, women, children, animals.' Response (resources: https://tinyurl.com/2NEFX888, https://www.str.org/w/why-a-good-god-commanded-the-israelites-to-destroy-the-canaanites): The command is tied to unique, unrepeatable covenant judgment on cultures saturated in entrenched evil (see Leviticus 18; Deuteronomy 9:4–5). It is not an open-ended license for violence but a specific, judicial act by God, who is the rightful judge of nations.

questions.prompt: How much contamination do we need before something is no longer pure?
questions.answer: Even small amounts of contamination affect purity. Just as gold loses its purity with minimal impurities, God's Word loses perceived trustworthiness when additions or omissions creep in—hence the seriousness of any modification.

questions.prompt: Why does God's Word withstand scrutiny? (Psalm 119:105; John 3:20)
questions.answer: God's Word is a lamp to our feet and a light to our path. God is not practicing evil—His Word welcomes exposure. Scripture can be examined intensely because truth stands up to pressure; hiding from scrutiny would undermine its claim to be light.

outline.summary: B — He is a shield to those who put their trust in Him
points: When we have a proper view of Scripture and of who God is, He promises to be a shield to us.
The shield of faith protects us specifically against 'all the fiery darts of the wicked one'—not against hardship, discomfort, or loss of reputation.
One of the most common ways we turn the shield in the wrong direction is by using it to protect who we believe ourselves to be.
The shield requires facing the right direction: toward the enemy's deceptions, not inward toward our own identity.

questions.prompt: What does it mean that He is a shield to those who put their trust in Him? How is it applied in our lives?
questions.answer: In Ephesians 6:10–18, the shield of faith protects us specifically against 'all the fiery darts of the wicked one'—not against hardship, discomfort, loss of reputation, or failed plans. The shield does not promise comfort or success; it allows us to withstand spiritual attacks and deception. When we apply Proverbs 30:5 correctly, we understand that God's purity and our trust in Him form a shield against spiritual lies and temptation.

questions.prompt: What are the 'fiery darts of the wicked one'? How do they differ from normal life struggles?
questions.answer: Fiery darts are temptations, lies, accusations, and deceptions from Satan—attacks meant to make us doubt God's character, goodness, or the reliability of His Word. These are spiritual attacks, distinct from normal hardships like job loss, illness, or relational conflict. The shield protects our faith from being shaken by these deceptions.

questions.prompt: How do we often turn the shield in the wrong direction—to protect our identity?
questions.answer: We turn the shield inward when we use our faith to defend our ego, reputation, or self-image rather than standing against deception about God. This happens when we become defensive about our beliefs instead of examining them, or when we reject truth that threatens our identity. A properly oriented shield faces outward toward the enemy's lies about God, not inward toward threats to our self-concept.

outline.summary: C — Warning About Adding and Taking Away
points: Deuteronomy 12:32: 'Whatever I command you, be careful to observe it; you shall not add to it nor take away from it.' This reflects God's value on the completeness and unchangeability of His Word.
Proverbs 30:5–6: 'Every word of God is pure…Do not add to His words lest you be found a liar.'
Colossians 2:20–22: When you follow human precepts and doctrines, you're adding to Scripture; when you discard clear biblical commands, you're taking away.
Revelation 22:18–19: The most severe warning—both adding to and taking away from Revelation specifically result in plagues and removal from the Book of Life.

questions.prompt: What does Deuteronomy 12:32 teach us about God's Word?
questions.answer: Deuteronomy 12:32 emphasizes that God's commands are complete as given—neither additions nor deletions are permitted. The warning reflects God's view of His Word as perfect and whole. Adding human ideas or traditions makes Scripture impure; removing hard sayings makes it incomplete. Careful observation and exact adherence honor God's authority and ensure we hear His actual message, not a distorted version.

questions.prompt: What is the final warning in Revelation 22:18–19?
questions.answer: Revelation 22:18–19 pronounces severe consequences: 'If anyone adds to these things, God will add to him the plagues that are written in this book; and if anyone takes away from the words of the book of this prophecy, God shall take away his part from the Book of Life, from the holy city, and from the things which are written in this book.' This is not merely about adding or removing individual verses—it is about the grave spiritual danger of modifying God's truth. God takes the integrity and purity of His Word with ultimate seriousness.

points: Context answers three questions Scripture never allows us to ignore: Who is being addressed? Why is this being said? How does this fit with the rest of what God has already revealed?
A verse without context can be quoted accurately and still be applied falsely.
Most misuse of Scripture does not begin with rebellion; it begins with careless or selective reading (2 Peter 3:16; Matthew 15:1–9).

questions.prompt: What three questions does context answer?
questions.answer: Context answers three essential questions Scripture never allows us to ignore: (1) Who is being addressed? (2) Why is this being said? (3) How does this fit with the rest of what God has already revealed? Context prevents us from isolating verses and misapplying them.

questions.prompt: How can a verse be quoted accurately but still be applied falsely?
questions.answer: A verse without context can be quoted accurately and still be applied falsely. For example, 'Jesus wept' (John 11:35) is accurate but meaningless without understanding the context of Lazarus's death and resurrection. Similarly, commands given to specific people in specific situations can be misapplied if torn from their context.

questions.prompt: Where does most misuse of Scripture begin?
questions.answer: Most misuse of Scripture does not begin with rebellion; it begins with careless or selective reading (2 Peter 3:16). Untaught and unstable people twist Scripture to their own destruction. The Pharisees' misuse of the law (Matthew 15:1–9) shows how human tradition can obscure God's command. Proper context ensures we hear the whole counsel of God (Acts 20:25–31) rather than a partial or distorted version.

content.html:
A. Introduction

I want to start this lesson with some caution and some reassurance. We are treading on ground that churches tend to avoid for a reason - there is a lot of power that we mostly ignore in scripture, a lot of spiritual things that we gloss over in my opinion to the detriment of our faith. However, when you aren't sure of the adherence of your congregation to the scriptures, when you can't be sure of their knowledge of scriptures, opening up to these types of discussions can cause more harm than good to those who are not a ways along in their walk.

1 Corinthians 3:1–3

NKJV

And I, brethren, could not speak to you as to spiritual people but as to carnal, as to babes in Christ. I fed you with milk and not with solid food; for until now you were not able to receive it, and even now you are still not able; for you are still carnal. For where there are envy, strife, and divisions among you, are you not carnal and behaving like mere men?

This avoidance has consequences. Many congregations remain at the level of simple gospel teaching—important for salvation but not sufficient for equipping believers against temptation or spiritual attack. The book of Ephesians calls believers to put on the whole armor of God to stand against “the wiles of the devil” (Ephesians 6:10–13). Without that preparation, faith remains shallow and vulnerable.

Ephesians 6:10–13

NKJV

Finally, my brethren, be strong in the Lord and in the power of His might. Put on the whole armor of God, that you may be able to stand against the wiles of the devil. For we do not wrestle against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this age, against spiritual hosts of wickedness in the heavenly places. Therefore take up the whole armor of God, that you may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand.

Luke 4:1–13 records Jesus’ temptation after forty days of fasting. Being full of the Holy Spirit, He was led into direct confrontation with Satan.

Luke 4:1–13

NKJV

Then Jesus, being filled with the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit into the wilderness, being tempted for forty days by the devil. And in those days He ate nothing, and afterward, when they had ended, He was hungry. And the devil said to Him, “If You are the Son of God, command this stone to become bread.” But Jesus answered him, saying, “It is written, ‘Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word of God.’ ” Then the devil, taking Him up on a high mountain, showed Him all the kingdoms of the world in a moment of time. And the devil said to Him, “All this authority I will give You, and their glory; for this has been delivered to me, and I give it to whomever I wish. Therefore, if You will worship before me, all will be Yours.” And Jesus answered and said to him, “Get behind Me, Satan! For it is written, ‘You shall worship the Lord your God, and Him only you shall serve.’ ” Then he brought Him to Jerusalem, set Him on the pinnacle of the temple, and said to Him, “If You are the Son of God, throw Yourself down from here. For it is written: ‘He shall give His angels charge over you, To keep you,’ and, ‘In their hands they shall bear you up, Lest you dash your foot against a stone.’ ” And Jesus answered and said to him, “It has been said, ‘You shall not tempt the Lord your God.’ ” Now when the devil had ended every temptation, he departed from Him until an opportune time.

This passage teaches several truths:

1) Temptation is unavoidable. Even Jesus was tempted. Paul reminds believers that “no temptation has overtaken you except such as is common to man”

1 Corinthians 10:13

NKJV

No temptation has overtaken you except such as is common to man; but God is faithful, who will not allow you to be tempted beyond what you are able, but with the temptation will also make the way of escape, that you may be able to bear it.

2) Victory depends on the Word of God. Each time Satan tempted Him, Jesus replied with Scripture. The spiritual battle is not fought with emotion or reason but with truth that is already written

Psalm 119:11

NKJV

Your word I have hidden in my heart, That I might not sin against You.

3) Temptation returns. Satan left “until an opportune time” (Luke 4:13). Spiritual vigilance must be continuous (1 Peter 5:8–9).

1 Peter 5:8–9

NKJV

Be sober, be vigilant; because your adversary the devil walks about like a roaring lion, seeking whom he may devour. Resist him, steadfast in the faith, knowing that the same sufferings are experienced by your brotherhood in the world.

We are often only taught man's methods for dealing with temptation, but man is fallible - God is sufficient for taking care of whatever spiritual problems come our way and He has shown us how these methods work by modelling our physical bodies after the same. 1) There is no instant cure. You don't get to recite a verse, or say a specific prayer and suddenly be cured of your temptation, just like you don't get to have a surgery or take a drug and instantly be healthy. There is recovery, there is physical therapy for retraining, there is time needed for medication to do what it needs to do.

2 Corinthians 4:16

NKJV

Therefore we do not lose heart. Even though our outward man is perishing, yet the inward man is being renewed day by day.

2) You are going to get sick. You're human, your immune system isn't perfect to protect you against sickness and your spirit isn't perfect to not be tempted or not fall to temptation - it's going to happen. Repent, turn away and take that next step towards God. Shame, worry, depression, anger, guilt - none of that is going to fix what you've done, just taking your next step towards God as soon as you can, accept His forgiveness and move forward.

1 John 1:9

NKJV

If we confess our sins, He is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

3) One size does not fit all of us. We are all created in the image of God, and we are all created unique. What works for one of us may not work for another - find what works for you and run towards it. Whatever version of the Bible that you read - read it, however you can calm your mind and hear the still small voice of God in prayer - do it, whatever denomination or church or group that helps you grow closer to Him (being careful of course of false doctrine) attend there. Our goal is to be more like Christ in everything that we do, and how we do that is going to be different for each of us.

Romans 12:4–6

NKJV

For as we have many members in one body, but all the members do not have the same function, so we, being many, are one body in Christ, and individually members of one another. Having then gifts differing according to the grace that is given to us, let us use them: if prophecy, let us prophesy in proportion to our faith;

And the promised reassurance - we are sealed by the Holy Spirit to God by our profession of faith in Christ. We may suffer the fiery darts of Satan while we are here (although - we have spiritual protection there too) we can have joy through all of it because we know our future.

Ephesians 1:13

NKJV

In Him you also trusted, after you heard the word of truth, the gospel of your salvation; in whom also, having believed, you were sealed with the Holy Spirit of promise,

No circumstance can remove us from the love of Christ

Romans 8:38–39

NKJV

For I am persuaded that neither death nor life, nor angels nor principalities nor powers, nor things present nor things to come, nor height nor depth, nor any other created thing, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Christ Jesus our Lord.

With that said - I want to break with tradition a bit and do communion a bit differently. Now - this is purely symbolic, I want everyone to keep in mind that while there is a ritual around this, we are not changed by the ritual, we are not affected by the elements, this is not "magic".

Paul instructed believers to examine themselves before partaking (1 Corinthians 11:27–29). The act of communion does not change the participant. It reminds us of Christ’s sacrifice and our unity in Him. “As often as you eat this bread and drink this cup, you proclaim the Lord’s death till He comes” (1 Corinthians 11:26). Communion is a time to shift attention from ritual to remembrance, to renew gratitude for redemption, and to reaffirm our hope as we await His return.

1) The Body of Christ We take this bread and think back to when we first accepted the gift that Christ went through so much to offer to us. When we first came alive in the spirit, when we first felt His love for us that emboldened us to take that first step in our lifelong walk trying to be more like Him. When Jesus said, “This is My body which is given for you; do this in remembrance of Me” (Luke 22:19), He established communion as a memorial, not a mystical transformation. We remember His suffering, the incarnation, and the substitution that brought us from death to life (Isaiah 53:5; Romans 5:8; John 5:24).

Father - help us to remember the decision we made, whether long ago or more recent, to follow after you. Remind us of the zeal that we felt for you at our first conversion, at our first baptism - how clean and new and alive you made us in one simple act of obedience. You have forgiven much, and have promised to continue to forgive us, not so we can do whatever we want, but so that we have assurance that while we are trying to follow after you that we aren't going to lose everything because we are imperfect.

2) The Blood of Christ Christ’s blood represents cleansing, reconciliation, and authority. “This cup is the new covenant in My blood” (1 Corinthians 11:25). Through that blood, believers are: Redeemed (Ephesians 1:7 “In Him we have redemption through His blood, the forgiveness of sins, according to the riches of His grace” ) Reconciled (Colossians 1:20–22 “and by Him to reconcile all things to Himself, by Him, whether things on earth or things in heaven, having made peace through the blood of His cross. And you, who once were alienated and enemies in your mind by wicked works, yet now He has reconciled in the body of His flesh through death, to present you holy, and blameless, and above reproach in His sight”)

Father, we come before You through Jesus Christ, who has disarmed the principalities and powers of this world at the cross. I reaffirm my salvation and my faith in You: nothing can separate me from Your love Lord Jesus, You are greater than he who is in the world. I submit to You fully. By Your Spirit, I put to death the deeds of this body and commit to resist the devil's schemes . I repent of every lie, every sin, every foothold I've given the enemy whether through unbelief, occult involvement, or unrepentant sin. Cleanse me by Your blood. Fill me with Your Holy Spirit, help me to equip Your full armor. Let Your Word dwell in me richly. I stand firm and confident in the victory You have already won. In Jesus' name, amen.
